From collecting eggs to raising a piglet until it’s being sent off to theslaughterhouse; we follow Hachiken’s struggle when he finds the truth of the harsh world of farming and searching for his goal, when all his new friends (mostly farmer’s heirs) already have their own.


The art in this show was pretty good and detailed. The food showed here makes you hungry just looking at it. The character designs were nice, with unique and funny appearances, and the animation seemed to go smoothly as well. I didn’t like the opening that much, but the overall soundtrack was good and the ending theme gives off this country feel, what makes it really fitting for this show.


The strength of Gin no Saji are the characters. Hachiken enters the school as an inexperienced, shy boy who knows nothing about farming, but struggles bravely with the challenges he gets thrown at him. We see him get sick when the head of a chicken gets chopped off and he gets overly attached to animals which are supposed to become food. We can all relate to at least some of his experiences. As the series continues, we see Hachiken’s character grow. All other characters are interesting as well and often funny, but never too unnatural what makes them look like real people with dreams and goals.


Sitting back in my chair or lying in bed, I enjoyed every episode of Gin no Saji. The show is easy to follow with subtle psychological themes like seeing cute little animals become your food, and the question whether you should eat it or not. But along with a bunch of hilarious scenes it was a light, heartwarming and very entertaining anime.


The second season of Gin no Saji will be airing this Winter season and I’m already looking forward to it! Since it’s my first review, I’m still a bit unsure about how to write them, but I hope you liked it nevertheless!

"Tokiwa, how can something so tasty come out of an anus?" - Hachiken
Every so often, we come upon an anime that isn't afraid to challenge the needs and wants of the industry. Gin no Saji, or Silver Spoon, is one such anime. It depicts the adolescent adventures of our young protagonist Hachiken who, despite having a strictly urban upbringing, decides to enrol in an agricultural school, full of budding farmers and the like.
While the preface may seem rather dull, I cannot stress how much I came to love and adore this series. And while Hachiken may be introduced as the main character, a massive castof side characters are included in every moment just as much as him. While some may see this as a weakness, thinking something along the lines of - "Just how much character development can be spread around in a measly 22 episodes?" - however, I personally find that this massive cast is one of the charms of this show. Every character has their ups and downs, and this just seems to continue to add colour to an already thriving atmosphere.


It appears that much of the more recent comedic releases rely heavily upon things like fanservice and ecchi scenes to entertain audiences. If this is what you're looking for, then I truly apologise for leading you on, as you'll find no scenes like that here, except for the pig/horse/cow variety. However, if you are looking for a truly artful comedy, one so cleverly designed as to have you laughing at the strangest things, Gin no Saji truly is the anime for you. 


From Hachiken's struggle in consuming eggs, to his attempted romantic advances, there is never a dull moment in this show. So in all seriousness, this truly is an anime to consider, if not an anime to watch, as a comedy like this may very well not only have you rolling around in tears of laughter, but also fundamentally challenge your outlook on food, farms, and every other aspect of life.

Gin no Saji's strength is that it's a 'high school' anime that's almost wholly original. By taking place in an agricultural school, it abandons most of the run-of-the-mill high school storylines. The main character flees his home to this farflung school for reasons that are only vaguely outlined during the show. The secondary characters are amusing, but have limited depth to them, and his love interest is almost one-dimensional. As such, this show is not really character-driven. It's about the novel new burdens of life that the protagonist has to accept at this school. If anything, the protagonist's increased understanding and respect for the foodchain becomes the main focus of the show; his own personal development doesn't seem to go anywhere. \n
Gin no Saji is different enough from other high-school series to warrant a viewing, but it doesn't excel in any specific respect. It is mildly amusing and just interesting enough to keep you going from one episode to the next.

If you thought this would be just a boring, agricultural slice of life anime, you're wrong. 
The first time that I watched it, I had to postpone watching halfway through episode 1 because I was not interested. I only checked it out because I heard that Hiromu Arakawa, the creator of Full Metal Alchemist created it. Due to the lack of good anime series to watch, I decided to watch all episodes. Unknowingly, this series provided entertainment and the humor is unique and entertaining. I thought that it all comes down to that, but there's more. The characterization is outstanding and you can see wellthe character development throughout the series. In this anime, you get to watch the characters work hard for their dreams, not a bunch of boobs and pantyshots. I related to the main protagonist Hachiken's situation and problem, for my parents often criticized my grades, flaws, and inability to do something. 


Overall, this series is a masterpiece. Hiromu Arakawa never failed me.

(No Spoiler)
Gin no Saji is a hidden treasure!
It's a deep and brilliant show, that will lead the viewer through farms, lifestocks and everything about them, especially the "everyday" aspect and the economic/moral issues. 
You'll "live" with and through the main character, even eggs and pork will taste different after this anime! 
So, Gin no Saji isn't a simple slice of life "watch and go", it's an opportunity to enjoy and learn about lives unkown to us, please try to watch it, it deserve an opportunity, even if you aren't in agricolture or economy.
Story and Characters are the power of this show, pay attention to details,every sentence and every action are part of the personality of the character.\n\n
WARNING: It isn't a recent anime (2011), so the art and the animation are quite outdated, but it's still beautiful, cause it was made properly at time.\n\n
Another note: Nowadays newest animes (and games) have usually great songs and sound, trying to gain attention through different openings and catching OST, Gin no Saji hasn't this feature, but for me it's not a big loss in this case, even if I usually love great OST.

*Spoiler free review:*
If you are looking for genuine life advice and motivation, or maybe you are looking for a good laugh, you may even just be looking for some time to pass. I can safely say that this anime is HIGHLY recommended to you. No matter who you are, anime fan or not, you can learn something from this anime. I was hesitant at first, going into the first episode my first impression was "ey, this art style kinda looks like full metal alchemist, I had no idea what I was getting into to be honest. I don't really read summaries or reviews before watchingor reading a new series. I like coming into a show with a fresh mindset, and that's what I did, and oh boy did I not expect to come eyes with one of my new favourite anime. (I'll try to keep this short) (ILL TRY!!).


Story: (8)

The story is great, it's not your generic slice of life anime rather a story about trail and error, facing hardships in life, making though life decisions and with great comedy at that. I found myself agreeing, surprised and overall laughing and having a great time, the story really put me in a inspirational and great mood. It's another one of those "Oh SNAP, I couldn't stop watching" type of series. "Don't watch at bed-time on a weekday if you treasure your sleep and don't like being fatigued in class or work". If you are anything like me, then you would not of been able to keep yourself away and sat up all night ruining your whole day for the sake of another anime.


Art: (8)

The art is good, I love the characters and environment, it's not my favourite art style but I grew to like it as the show progressed, the animation isn't breath taking either, but it does the job, it's a well put together anime, therefore the art is a strong 7.


Sound: (8)

I'm not an expert of sound, but I can easily differentiate from good quality anime and bad quality anime just from it's audio samples. The voice acting is decent, the animal sounds are good and he overall sounds are good, apart from that there isn't really anything that stands out except for the ED which I really enjoyed and was looking forward to through out every episode. (I'm usually a big fan of Ending Songs).


Character: (8)

I really loved the character development in this one, I'v said this in another review before but I really look for characters that stand out and leave impressions in anime, it's something I sought after.

All the characters really did leave a good impression on me, they all have unique interesting personalities that each shine in their own ways. It's hard to get bored with all of these awesome personalities on your screen.


Enjoyment: (10)

It's been a long long time since an anime made me feel this enjoyed, It's been a while since i'v been motivated and just overall felt good about watching an anime. Not only was it educational but it was funny too, which really lifts my mood. I did not expect to laugh so hard to the jokes that were cracked in the anime, maybe it's just me that have a weird sense of humour but I doubt that as I laugh together with people all the time, and If this anime makes me laugh, I'm sure it will make you laugh too, It's really hard not to ( I'm being serious here ). 


Overall: (9)

A strong 9, I'd like to give it more, but In the end it's no Akira or Made in abyss we are talking about here, it's not a Ghibli movie either. It's a good slice of life comedy anime with good education value and life advice. ( That was a weird sentence, lol ). But yeah, recommend this to anyone anime fan or not, worth your time, maybe you will learn something useful?


Sorry for grammatical errors, I'm confident in my use of grammar, but then again I always hurriedly type down these review because that's what I do. Hope they did not throw you off my review and hope you found it helpful. ( It's easy to make errors ). I'm only human after-all, "we all make mistakes, it's inevitable, the only time you can't afford to make mistakes is when lives are at stake".


You will appreciate that last sentence a lot more after watching the show!

I definitely didn't expect much from this anime. but that got blown out of the water pretty fast.
The story is nice and easy to follow, the art is simple but great to look at, the characters are very endearing and they make you feel and want too root for them, you also learn a lot of interesting things about the farming industry whilst watching this show. 
You can really empathize with the characters problems since since most of them are so relatable such as money problems and not knowing what you want to do with your life.
i definitely recommend this show :3

This was one of the first anime I finished (probably 3rd or 4th). 
Hachiken Yuugo could be a relatable character for most people. I can relate to him and many of my friends can to. 
His life at home is where his dad cares for him to improve and wants him to be better but shows it in a way Hachiken would want to run away. His brother was the one that satisfied their dad but it only ended up where he dropped out of Tokyo University.
He has no dreams and goals so, all he wants to do is go to school. He picked hisschool because he wouldn't have to go home and face his dad. Therefor he learns about farm studies.\n\n
Out of all the characters, my most favorite is probably Komaba. He worked hard in school, tried his best in athletic stuff, but that wouldn't work to help his family. He ended up dropping out of school leaving Aki sad.

Free of spoilers and English is not my national language
Story: Its plot is not one of the best, but it leaves nothing to be desired. It has a very good balance, bringing comedy and romance at the right time. Its creator is Hiromu Arakawa, a legend of Japan and creator of the famous work Fullmetal Alchemist, making the plot of Gin in the Saji a true peculiarity. THIS REVIEW COVERS BOTH  SEASONS OF GIN NO SAJI
   Did you know that Fullmetal Alchemist is not Hiromu Arakawa's only work? Because it sure doesn't seem like it. So many people loved FMA but the thought of watching other anime adaptations from the same author's works never crossed their minds. Everything else she has made is so overshadowed it's not even funny. Well, in hopes of changing that, I'm going to tell you about Silver Spoon, which is based on her most recent manga with the same name.Silver Spoon is the exact opposite of Fullmetal Alchemist, it is a slice of life comedy with elements of romance and a particular take on the school genre. This is because "Rather than writing another fantasy series like Fullmetal Alchemist, Arakawa wanted to challenge herself by trying a more realistic story with Silver Spoon" (From Hiromu Arakawa's Wikipedia page). Instead of sticking to a proven-to-work formula, Silver Spoon is the work of a passionate mangaka who is not afraid of experimenting with concepts she has never delved into before, resulting in a show that is clearly more than just the typical boring RomCom slice of life.


   The story follows Yugo Hachiken, a teenager who was not able to score grades high enough to enroll in his parents' university of choice. His dad reacted extremely negatively to this, and Hachiken, tired of the constant pressure to have amazing grades, decides to join a school dedicated to agriculture and areas related to it. There he learns what it means to live in the world of agriculture.


   Sounds boring, doesn't it? The reason for that is that there are very few stories that deal with normal, everyday life. It is, in fact, hard to make an interesting story out of such concepts, and most writers are not skilled enough to deal them, and so they add something to spice things up. However, this is not the case with Silver Spoon. There is no need for fanservice or flashy visuals. Instead, Silver Spoon's strength is in its characters. Yes, the show can be boring at times due to lack of cool action fights or complex sci fi worlds, but Silver Spoon is not about keeping the viewer on the edge of his seat all the time. Instead, it keeps us interested simply by having a setting that feels plausible, and characters that feel real. No heroes, villains, geniuses, psychopaths or any other archetypes. Just regular teenagers, living their normal life (though the quirkiness of an agricultural school limits the term "normal" a bit). But normal isn't always boring. Everyone living person has dreams and ambitions, as well as their own personal struggles. And the same can be said about most everyone in Silver Spoon. MOST everyone. Unfortunately, so many characters are introduced on the span of 22 episodes that it becomes near impossible to flesh out each of them. These underdeveloped characters are sadly what brings this show down. Silver Spoon could've beneffited drom introducing less characters, or from having double the episodes per season.


   Moving onto the story, Silver Spoon is a strict slice of life, and focuses entirely on the everyday life of the people in the school. The first episodes are interesting and different enough from other slice of life to grab your interest. During the introduction, the show does a good job with presenting many of the students, each of them have different reasons for joining that school and have interest in a specific area of the agricultural life. This gives them a distinct personality as well as opportunities to interact and talk to Hachiken, while explaining how the school works.


   As the show progresses, we are presented with a lot of situations that make Hachiken, and even the viewer, question their way of seeing things. He is faced with the problems like the killing of farm animals for mankind's convenience. He also has to deal with his own personal struggles, like his relationship with his parents, and even later on in the second season he ends up falling in love with a girl he is friends with. Although shown in a light fashion, these themes are a good addition to the show, and help Hachiken grow as a person.


   Not a lot can be said about the ending of the anime, since the manga is still ongoing, but there are various unresolved conflicts that deserve exploration, hinting that a third season might be on the works. My only problems with the story by the end of the second season were that some arcs felt like a bit of a waste of time, especially during the episodes the blond snob girl is introduced. Time that could've been used to flesh out previously introduced characters.


   For an anime that aired during 2013/2014, the visuals are pretty good, which is to be expected from A-1 Pictures. The animation is fluid, and didn't have any noticeable quality drops. The farm animals and the backgrounds in particular looked very detailed.


  Sound-wise, they did a decent job with the voice actors, they fit the characters they played for the most part, and again, special attention was paid to the animals, they sounded very realistic. Soundtrack, for the most part, fit the setting of the anime, and the intro and outro songs in particular will still be enjoyable well after finishing the show.


   Overall, despite having some weak characters and not always being consistent with the plot, Silver Spoon was made with passion, which is noticeable throughout its duration of 22 episodes. It has a strong cast to which you can relate to, charming visuals, and due to its unusual setting, it deals with themes relating to the agricultural world that are not often found anywhere else. It is highly recommended for people who like slice of life anime and are interested in checking out other works from the writer of Fullmetal Alchemist.

Ever wondered what you should do with your life? 
The sheer pressure of making something worthwhile of one's life has probably hit many of us at least one point in life. Maybe that's why Hachiken's struggle hits so close to home.
Maybe that's also why I quickly marathoned every episode hoping that he would find his answer by the end of it all. Though following his journey I together with him discovered that there's other important things that requires your attention and that if you don't force it, the answer will surely come one day. If you think too much about it, you will miss alot of fun things that you will never be able to get back.


Silver spoon is a light hearted SOL that is fitting for everyone, whether you are interested in agriculture or not the way it present itself to the viewer makes it really interesting. 


Together with its seemingly large cast it makes for a hilarious trip through its 12 episodes. It's difficult to not like every single one of them and to certain degrees emphatize with their struggles because it feels so real.


Though a lot happens through the episodes, plot wise not a lot develops and by the end of it, everyone is basically the same. But that's ok, because the charm is the humor, characters and overall light hearted tone that makes Silver spoon a fun, heart warming ride. While you won't come out as a new person after watching it, you will hopefully end it with a smile on your face just like I did as you click on season 2.

This was for me a very interesting and enjoyable story line. This anime had the focus on the farming element while developing the characters and there relationships. It as very innocent in many way and fun in it uniqueness. It kept the viewer engaged through both drama and comedy and very light heart-ed romance. It struck a good balance between these element to make the story very engaging.
The art was nice. There was no issue that stood out and it was pleasant to watch.  The sound was good the intro music I found enjoyable and overall the audio in the series was good. 
Thecharacter make up was good. Having a nice mix of personality types and not an heavy overbearing main character elements. Some of the side character didn't really get that much screen time which is a shame but does not detract from the story at all.\n\n
Overall this was a very enjoyable series for me. It had a unique story and interesting character. Telling a fun and comedy filled plot in a all 11 episodes. I would recommend it to any one who wants a different slice of life anime with no desire for ecchi stuff.

Story: 8
The anime follows a city boy's school life as he tries to assimilate into an environment completely new to him, exploring themes such as realisation of the things people take for granted, lack of direction in life and personal morals. Though it sounds very cliched and somewhat disheartening/depressing, this anime in contrast is very mellow and light-hearted and is filled with heart warming moments and humour.
Even though I gave the story a 9 it does not mean it is particularly unique, however the execution and pacing is superb. The flow throughout the series very consistent and you'll unlikely find periodswhere you lose focus. The anime keeps it's direction and rarely sidetracks or forces cliched or stereotypical scenes and/or interactions between characters to occur.



Characters:  9

The strongest point regarding this anime (in my opinion) and is what carries the relatively straightforward plot to awesomeness. Characters here are well rounded and have many facets to their personality, usually behaving how you'd expect them to (though this does not by any means mean that they are predictable). Comedic and over the top reactions as you would expect in any comedy/slice of life anime can be found here too though the anime will not overuse this to the point it becomes stale.


The cast size is reasonable and there is plenty of interactions and conversations between them to create a feeling that the anime actually takes place within a somewhat populated area (of course it has to, it's a school!). By this I do not mean the main characters give a passing comment frequently, but the side characters are well involved with the story and have a fair share in screen time.



Art: 7

The art here is not one of the best out there or so brilliant that it's dazzling but in conjunction with other aspects of this anime it is very well done. It to a certain degree is realistic (no i don't mean it like like real life). Characters are mostly drawn such that they reflect their personality but is not done over the top such as the thickheaded class clown guy looking like a crazy nut who was dropped on their head as a baby. This being said, there are eccentric looking characters scattered here and their but they mainly serve as comedy relief or support for the main character and don't get as much focus or screen time.

Scenery and colours used here reflect the mood well, usually bright and warm to add the the relaxing mood but when necessary it will adapt to more serious scenes.

Before I get into this review, I should warn folks that this series may not be for everyone as it is a slice-of-life title, a far cry from Hiromu Arakawa's previous hit title Fullmetal Alchemist. In addition, aspects of the farming lifestyle it explores such as animals giving birth and the slaughtering of animals for food may not be pleasant for some sensitive viewers. If you're expecting the grand plot and action that FMA delivered with this title or something clean with its content, I would strongly suggest you do not look into Silver Spoon any further. However if you enjoy slice-of-life titles or arelooking for a title that is different from the norm compared to many recent anime offerings, this could be the title for you.


Silver Spoon focuses on high school student Yugo Hachiken who enrolls at an agricultural school in the countryside and finds himself adjusting to the rather different environment he is living in as he was living in Sapporo before moving to the boonies. The series mixes around comedy and drama as Hachiken adjusts to his new living environment, befriends students at the school and tries to determine what he hopes to get out of his learning. A good amount of the comedy from the series comes from Yugo's reactions to the farming environment that he is mostly alien to and some of the seemingly eccentric quirks to his classmates brought about from having experienced farming their entire life. The comedy to this mostly delivered well for me mostly since it felt natural in the adjustment to a different lifestyle that Hachiken had to adjust to, though some of the comedic bits do usually fall flat or feel overused.


The drama from Silver Spoon comes from Hachiken and his classmates learning from one another throughout their ordeals at the agricultural school. Hachiken comes to understand the rigorous work and tough decisions that many of the students have to make in order to maintain their way of life. In return, Hachiken's outsider perspective on farming, as he comes to learn more about it, lead his classmates to consider aspects of their regular routines that they took for granted as they considered them natural due to being brought up on them their entire lives. Hachiken and several of the students get their characters fleshed out so we get to learn more about their family lives and what they hope to gain through their learning at the agricultural school. The farming elements to the series (riding horses, selling and raising animals for meat or produce, being up early to care for farming duties, etc...) are believably portrayed thanks to Arakawa's own personal upbringing of living on a dairy farm growing up, an aspect that anime fans who live on farms could possibly relate with. The series lacks a proper ending as its source material is still ongoing, though a second season of Silver Spoon has since been made and I look forward to adding it to my physical collection of anime whenever Aniplex releases it.


Visually, the scenery for this sports vivid color and a good amount of detail showing off its rural settings and even having realistically-drawn animals, with some occasions they are rendered in super-deformed design for comedic gags. The character designs are nothing out of the ordinary, though they are reasonably detailed and there is variety in how characters are drawn. The animation is also a bit on the subpar side at points, though it isn't really the prominent element of Silver Spoon. The music for the series consists of a laid-back and mellow soundtrack that is fitting for its intended focus on rural life.


Silver Spoon won't be for everyone thanks to its slice-of-life genre and focusing on a theme that would seem to appeal to a niche audience. Still, it believably portrays the rigorous work and tough decisions that a farming lifestyle brings to those who experience it and Hachiken's role as observer to it make it an engaging experience as he comes to deal with the everyday challenges that farming brings to the students at the agriculture school. The series is definitely worth a look if you like slice-of-life, live life in the boonies or are looking for something out of the ordinary for an anime title.

Cock-a-doodle-doo!
“Damn rooster,” you think, as you wake up, wiping goop from your eyes. It’s only four in the morning, and yet, you’ve got the stables to clean, the pigs to feed, the cows to milk, eggs to collect, and man, does your life suck.
But you start to realize that by working so hard, you’ve become the tough and caring person you are today. You’re shaped by what’s around you in this world, come hell or high water. Hiromu Arakawa, the mangaka behind the critically acclaimed, “Fullmetal Alchemist,” has made the perfect story of demonstrating this effect.
“Gin no Saji,” or “Silver Spoon” as translated in English,is a Slice of Life/Comedy-Drama about a young man’s experiences with his classmates and his newfound farm life after he enrolls in Yezo High, an agricultural high school. 


--this review is SPOILER free, contains a tl;dr, and IS for both seasons--



---PLOT---

What better way to explore the themes of life and growth than with life itself? 


I know what you’re thinking, but this series does something a little different than the usual SoL/Comedy-Drama, which makes the aforementioned idea of life being explored with the use of life itself completely applicable. Instead of some generic high-school setting that we’ve seen more than a thousand times, the characters are living in an incredibly unique backdrop; an agricultural school, filled with cattle, combines, and corn. I’ve never seen a setting such as this, they grow and harvest crops, they take care of animals, milk cows, ride horses, the whole nine yards.


Given Arakawa’s track record, she knows how to handle her storytelling, and Silver Spoon is no exception. Immediately, it delves into the hardships of farm life and the both physical and emotional tolls people who live said lives have to pay. From getting up early in the morning just to work yourself half to death, to seeing an animal you grew attached to and spent countless hours raising get sent to the slaughterhouse. There’s even cows…


…giving birth. In great detail.


Oh boy.


These happenings within the very simple story of Silver Spoon serve doubly as both comedic relief and harsh characterization. The characters grow as people through the difficult missions they’re tasked with and the environment they’re surrounded by. While the series is filled with comedy, (and this time around with Arakawa’s story, it doesn’t feel out of place or interrupt story flow, most likely due to the flexible setting) there’s quite a lot of crushingly realistic problems in the story which are never handled immaturely, such as animal euthanization and entire families in debt. It genuinely affects the people in the series, from initial reactions, to how they end up coping with their problem. It takes time, effort, and resources to live even the simplest of lives, and equally so with farming.


And even though the mangaka grew up on a dairy farm, it’s obvious through the amount of various information on animals and the food industry that she did not skip doing her extended research. There’s a vast array of trivia throughout the series (usually revealed through dialogue) about chromosomes, animal cloning, food production, breeding, and much more that has to do with the harshness of the farming industry. 


So, as far as subtle growth through life experiences and hardship goes, this series is almost unmatched. There’s just one, glaring problem.


The conclusion.


We got another go read the manga ending? Dammit.


This series technically concludes, but given where and how, (as well as the entire setting anyway) there is SO much more room for more. As far as I know, there is no third season, and this is beyond unfortunate, because it feels like there is a lot of completely unused potential. We’re left on an anticlimactic note; with no actual closing statement to any of these character’s lives. So unless we get that third cour, this story isn’t really over enough to be anything truly brilliant. But with what was given to us, we did get some absolutely amazing, emotional, and downright pure reality. 

---Plot Score: -Great- ---




---CHARACTERS---

There’s something this story is before anything else. 


It’s character driven. 


Yugo Hachiken is the protagonist of the story. He came to Yezo a bespectacled introvert, obsessed with his ability to conquer everyone around him academically. A person like him obviously does not initially enjoy his newfound country life, but it’s that realism throughout the series that causes him to grow in many different ways.  


Through Hachiken’s experiences on the farm, his friends become his extended family, and his entire outlook changes as he realizes that it’s not about status or superiority over others; but the bonds you share with them, and the path you take in life while admiring the small things, and your endless options. Options you have to earn to get to.

He comes out a hardworker, with only the well-beings of his friends on his mind, even if there are a few screw-ups along the way, but who doesn’t mess up? That’s his humanity speaking for itself, it takes a long time for people to truly change, and when the journey is portrayed in the way it is here, there’s no room for disappointment. 


For the other characters, we have Mikage Aki, the “girl next door,” and quite possible Hachiken’s romantic interest in the series. She loves horses, (what girl doesn’t love horses these days in the teen drama, right?) and is living at her parent’s ranch. Then there’s Ichiro; a farm boy whose only dream is to make it to baseball’s big leagues and support his farm with the money he earns. 


There are other various characters as well, and to be quite honest, a lot of them are extremely stereotypical. The over-protective dad, the supportive teacher, the goofball, the list goes on. But it’s their chemistry as regular, everyday people that make their interactions work. Silver Spoon prides itself on how the characters learn that they need to persevere to be, both for themselves and those around them, thinking both in the moment to the future, but never to the past. It is here and now that we need to be living in; as we won’t get anything done otherwise.


Their interactions; both the humorous ones and the realistic ones, are what really make the series priceless. Sometimes it’s adorable. And sometimes, it pulls at your heartstrings, and the transitions are never off-handed. It’s easily shown that the most effort was put into the cast.

---Characters Score: -Amazing- --




---ANIMATION---

The look of the series is actually very well done, the smoothness of everything fits perfectly and the style is extremely “friendly,” if I can put it that way. The character designs and detailed background artwork is all very inviting and pleasant to look at. There’s also a lot of color and detail in both the food and the foliage around the school.


Even if the characters stand around a lot, (which makes for a lot frames with nothing but moving lips) the series isn’t supposed to be action oriented. Though, it would have been nice to have some movement, and…


No they didn’t


Oh shit that’s


WHY?


COMIC SANS? REALLY? They translate all of the Japanese credits into English using COMIC SANS? F***!


And what’s up with the CG animals? I’m done complaining about 3D, it is now something I must accept with grace, but geez.

So overall, the look of the anime is very nice and clean, even with the manure. 

---Animation Score: -Great- ---




---SOUND---

I was waiting to get here, for one reason. At first, the soundtrack didn’t sound that great, until I realized one thing.


It’s all country. 


Did you HEAR me? Japanese Country! I’ve never ever heard of these things being combined before, and for the series, both openings, (“LIFE” by Fujifabric and “kiss you” by MIWA) have the same sound-dynamics and instrument usage of traditional Bluegrass/Country, with Japanese vocals. 


Regardless of taste, for the series, it fits EXTREMELY well. For the actual soundtrack, there’s a lot of woodwind and piano that also fits with the welcoming atmosphere. Also, what’s that instrument? That’s commonly used in Pokemon games?


Specifically the third generation?


Trumpets. Lots of trumpets. 

---Sound Score: -Amazing- ---


AFTER REPORT:


PROS: 

-	Extremely realistic story, with perfectly placed drama that causes characters to mature as human beings, and learn valuable life lessons

-	Refreshing comedy that fits into the story like a puzzle piece

-	Subtle but brilliant transformation of the main character, fantastic interactions and chemistry within the cast

-	Informative about the harshness of the food industry

-	Touchingly mature, and one of a kind setting

-	Amazing, unique and fitting soundtrack

-	Solid animation

-	I’m putting this here because it’s downright RARE to see in anime; it is actually very “clean”. There is a little bit of innuendo (and cow porn mags) but to be honest that is nothing out of the ordinary for a PG movie. If possible, this series is perfect for a family


MIXED:

-	You know at the end of it all it isn’t action oriented or “exciting,” so many viewers may not see it as entertaining.


CONS:

-	Lack of a definite conclusion makes the already good series feel it holds baggage of wasted potential. 

-	Doesn’t go to lengths to flesh out as many characters as it could have with the setting



OVERALL: -Amazing-

So for those of you who really want a simple story of self-discovery, hard work, and perseverance, Silver Spoon is absolutely for you. It’s cute at times, and incredibly sad at others. It is life in a nutshell. 


Fans of Arakawa’s work may be a bit put off to the incredibly different setting and story from FMA, but she further shows her prowess as a brilliant storyteller. I look forward to a possible third cour. 


Silver Spoon gets a 9 from me, good job!

Most mediums of storytelling tend to focus on Urban and suburban life. The life of farming is usually an unwanted bore. Not only because stories are rarely told in this setting, but because when I say I'm in real country land people usually comment about how boring that must be. 
So I was pleasantly surprised upon hearing about Silver Spoon (AKA Gin no Saji). Especially since it would focus on a school that actually taught agricultural studies. Where it would focus on the animals, science, and such of farming. From large scale setups to small family ones. I was mainly curious to see the similaritiesto dissimilarities  of Japan and USA farming. (Though I didn't see it addressed that limited space means Japan uses a lot of high tech things to utilize space. No open range farming, which I'm used to.) I also like that they address bacteria, regulations, and disease as important parts of farming.


Overall it's very similar. And I found very few errors. (Though the should emphasis that when dealing with pigs or hogs you do not get friendly. A neighbor got mauled by her seemingly sweet pig. She lost her thumb, part of her thigh, and calf. If she hadn't been wearing sweats by accident she would have had her leg severed. It's not an uncommon thing. An aunt had a chunk bit out of her thigh. And the hog farms literally have signs warning you about pig mauling.) As a chicken farmer I was bummed about not focusing more on them, but that's just preference. (Though I've never seen an egg come out wet before. Maybe they were trying to emphasize that the egg is briefly soft before the air hardens it?) It was really fun getting some city views. Like the egg does come out of the cloaca, which shares it's purpose with pooping. 


I adored the characters! From Hachiken who was just learning about animals and farming, to the experienced heirs to their family farms. I loved how each character developed and added to the story. The romance isn't the main focus it accompanies the story of Hachicken learning about agriculture. (To be honest it's more of a one sided crush.) 


I loved that it even brought focus on the ethical questions of livestock. They're not pets and one can get numb to the fact that their lives are short as they become food. If chickens don't lay, food. If a cow gets injured it's cheaper to put them down. Handling and livestock is constantly handling lives. I enjoyed that Hackiken's newness to the concept brought up a lot of questions. For those used to the idea and such. Even how vets have to make tough calls about healing an animal and knowing when to put them down. Even briefly touching on slaughter houses.


As someone who lives around farms and has helped as a farmhand I enjoyed it. Especially since my chickens are pets and I like them to retire into ripe old ages. I've dealt with the reality of having to put down a loved one because of illness. 


Don't worry though, the majority of the story is very heart warming. It focuses on the dreams and goals of it's characters. I also enjoyed that while there is a certain comfort to being an heir, a lot of times it's the only options. Most farmers do not make a lot of money. I'm curious if they'll ever address the restrictions of the government on forming. The story did touch lightly on large scale and small scale farming. 


I really liked the look of the art, especially when it came to the animals. They were still anime cute, while being realistic. Especially when they were meat. ^_- The scenery is gorgeous and I think it captured the look and feel of farming beautifully. 


I like that the arc of this season's story was wrapped up. So even if a season 2 had not come out we'd have some closure. I love the characters and look forward to them. I can't wait to see what the next season brings. What animals will be focused on. Not to mention what will happen to the many shiny eyed, and hopeful, characters the next season. I enjoyed that I spent most of the time smiling during Silver Spoon. But I still got teary eyed despite knowing how things go the way of the slaughter house. Well done.

''Gin no Saji: Harvest Moon Nostalgia!''
Gin no Saji, or Silver Spoon is an experimental series for me. and i was surprised that this series amuse me a lot

What makes Gin no Saji's story amuse me is, execpt Hachiken, all the students there seems to have their own aspiration, Hachiken, with lack of ambitions, learn that sooner or later he's got to find his own goals. And also apparently, he's in crush with Mikage, cute member of the equestrian club, which encourage Hachiken to join the club, too.


And i guarantee that Gin no Saji has a very good comedy side, like when Hachiken realize that egg come from chicken's anus, and refused to eat them for a while. So lives in Gin no Saji is never getting so bored after all, and that's a good thing.


Art 8/10

If you looked at my profile page, it's clear that i'm fans of KyoAni. I won't say that Gin no Saji has a very bad art, it's good, natural and acceptable, but just that. Well at least everything looks fluid, although i'll be happier if the background (mostly farm and livestocks) could be brighter. Hope that the 2nd season could be better though..


Sound 7/10

Probably the weakest aspect of Gin no Saji. The OP and ED is impressive, but the background sound? it's utterly suck. I expected daily farm-feel on the background sound, but what i found is just medicore Slice of Life-feel. Well it's SOL show but it won't fit the story that's has a lot of

potential, though. dissapointing.


Character 9/10

This is the strongest point of Gin no Saji. I love to see Hachiken developed over time as he struggling with the new world that actually don't fit on him. And his contradicts background lives with his friend makes him so different in terms of treat the animals in the school, which is

shown greatly episode by episodes.


Enjoyment 8/10

I'm fans of high quality artworks, and it's a shame that i can't enjoy much aesthetics stuff from Gin no Saji. But the lack of great art is perfectly coverd with great story. The comedies is fresh, and it's somehow, remind me of Harvest Moon, on of my favorite game ever!


Of course Gin no Saji has a lot of potential and i'm really expecting a lot of surprising stuff shown in the 2nd season.


Overall 8/10

There's not much to say in the end. I would say that Gin no Saji is a very promising series and the sequel is what i anticipated the most. i expecting a 

bit romcom between Hachiken and Mikage, but just don't too much drama of course. Life can be hard, especially in farm. But hard things always come along with fun things too.


''It's okay to run away in order to live. It's entirely okay!''

First of all, if you are reading this review to give you some ideas to decide whether to watch it or not, I’d say “just bookmark it” because you wouldn’t easily find much realistic farm life Anime that is so enjoyable and relaxing like “Silver Spoon”.
For a general description on the Anime, you might read the synopsis or some other sources to get info on that. Thus, I’d make this review clear-cut as to why this Anime is very interesting: 
1. Hachiken’s life is so realistic that can be related at some points such as the indecisiveness on the future goal, the difficulty of suddentransformation from urban lifestyle to agricultural lifestyle, the fun of having friends being around, the joy of hardworking and so on. \n
2. The author, Hiromu Arakawa has done a lot of research regarding the agricultural practices, especially related to livestock farming. Besides being able to enjoy Anime, it is no doubt that we get to know some knowledge and techniques on how modern agriculture works. \n
3. Seeing how food can be so delicious with freshly collected ingredients in their own farm, it makes you wanna have a life like that just because of the tasty food. \n
4. On top of that, the beautiful OPT and EDT are really well-suited for the Anime by adding refreshing flavours to the Anime. \n
5. But most importantly, the Anime may not make you laugh out loud, but it will certainly put a smile on your face after each episode without realising it. Why can I be so confident about this? Experience it yourself and try to prove me wrong if you can :P \n\n
Anyways, if you ever find yourself liking it afterwards, I have a good news, season 2 is there for you :) \n

A very refreshing calm anime that takes place in an agriculture university. 
It tells the story of a city boy who ran away from home to this university in order to find who he is as a person in spite of his lost thoughts. We watch as Hachike learn about life at farms, food-making process, make relations with animals and hobbies that include horses, and in general enjoy/struggle with his new way of life.
A very enjoyable anime with distinct characters.  
It tends towards the comedy genre and it truly has some moments that made me laugh out loud.
Definitely, a must watch to ease one'smind.\n\n

Months ago, I watched the first half of the first episode of this anime, and I decided to invest my time in something else, because what could be interesting about farming? 
Having finished season 1, I couldn't be happier that I decided to take it up again.
Silver Spoon follows Hachiken, a high school boy who finds himself in a situation that many of us can relate to on a very personal level. He feels directionless in life, doesn't know what he wants to do with himself, so he makes the decision to attend a farming boarding school out in the country, despite having no particularinterest in the field.


If one thing in Silver Spoon stuck out to me, it was how it looks at life. Watching the series feels like receiving a life lesson from your wise old grandfather. And Hachiken, being possibly one of the most realistic and relate-able characters in anime, is a character you can seamlessly put yourself in the shoes of. 


As the show goes on, an overarching theme is that of death and the cycle of life. Our MC finds himself getting to attached to baby pig, after he decides to name it, knowing that it is born and raised for slaughter. As we watch this pig grow, we're confronted with extremely profound questions. Things like, if he was born for slaughter, what is the point of his life at all? Watching this, and all the other things going on around the farm school, really shows us how interconnected the cycle of life is.


Rather than just giving us a simple message of "Be a vegetarian", this mundane sounding issue delivers an amazingly profound message about life. But at the same time, it doesn't just shove its morals in our face. In all the lessons Hachiken learns throughout each episode, we often feel just as lost as he does when faced with these dilemmas. But all in all, you walk away from season 1 feeling as though you've grown along with Hachiken.


Although, there are a few places where it falls short. None of these things are by any means bad, but things like the comedy and music could be better. They do their job, but they don't stand out. The side characters are good, and a select few we get to see in a deeper light, and I am hoping to see more development in season 2. The animation is rather good, and the only flaw I can point out about that, is just that it didn't do better.


All in all, Silver Spoon teaches us something about life. Not always through wise words, but through the feelings we experience along with Hachiken as he makes his way through this diverse high school life. You can always point out exactly what you've taken away from it, but no doubt, you walk away knowing more about the big picture regarding life as a whole.


Ya'll should watch this series. (But if you're touchy with animal death, be forewarned there is a bit of that. I would still recommend it to you)

AGRICULTURE!!!!
This show somehow makes farming super engaging, so props for that right off the start. The story centers around Hachiken, second son of a upper class family. He chose the school only because it was literally the farthest away he could get from his toxic home life (which they only get into in the second season).
So, knowing nothing about earth science, dairy science or agriculture at large. The show mostly follows him learning about the farm life, and all the modern science, business and labor that goes into it. And it this sounds boring I promise it's not.
Yes this is a slice of life inall means, but, I just found myself drawn in to the characters and where it as was going.

Alright, so this is an anime about the arguably harsh reality of farming and working with livestock. Gotta say, it gets points for originality right out the gate.
I'm gonna start with the one and only issue I had about this anime, and that is the main character's motivation and reason for being at this agricultural school being pushed to the background. Essentially, you go into this anime knowing that the main character is out of place in this environment because of his background, but that's all you know. There's no foundation in flashback or exposition that actually makes you, as the viewer, feel that thisis an unusual situation for the main character. So, seeing this character struggle at this school doesn't really hold the same type of weight as it could had his background been expanded on. It kind of felt like the dynamic of him being a city boy in the boonies wasn't necessary. 


That being said, I know that this anime is more about message than story. The overall theme of this anime is about forging one's own path and working hard to make it happen. Demonstrating that theme through an anime like this is very original and enjoyable to watch. Using animals as catalysts for real life conflicts, I think, was a great way to portray the message of this anime. 


For what it's worth, this anime made me think, and that's probably what kept me hooked most of the time. It's hard to say what makes this anime so enjoyable to watch, especially since it doesn't really come with a lot of big plot twists or developments, but it's not an empty story. Honestly, if you're interested in this anime, give it a shot, because you might find something in it that you wouldn't expect.

I dunno if I can express how much I enjoyed Gin no Saji! I have a very soft spot for stories about farming - the idea of connecting to the land and labor that sustain us as a therapeutic experience - but Gin no Saji captures this idea so perfectly and so sincerely. It's really, really sweet. 
Arakawa's best known for sprawling fantasy epics like Fullmetal Alchemist, but I think it's in character-driven slice-of-life stories like this where her talents really shine; Gin no Saji is smart, funny and carefully written, able to linger on its subtle character work and thematic beats in ways somethinghuge, like Fullmetal, simply can't. There's a special and simple wisdom that comes from agriculture, with its direct connection to life (and sometimes death), that Arakawa understands intimately and expresses with loving, detailed attention here. Gin no Saji is a show as gentle-spirited and fun as it is illuminating.


It's also just plain cute.  The farm animals are absolutely adorable, especially the pigs and dogs - the rounded, cartoonish visual style lends itself really well to this. Though the show never lacks tension and conflict, it also never feels overly dark; its mature concerns and conflicts are managed within its lighthearted, optimistic tone.  


It's absolutely worth the watch, especially if you're having a hard day (or in my case, a hard several years lol). I promise you'll come out of it feeling better.

This review does not contain any spoilers.
--Story--
First of all, when I downloaded this anime I didn't look at the plot. I usually download animes regarding their score and genre and this looked quite good, had a good source to watch it so I decided to try it out. Watched the first episode and I was SHOCKED. 
IT IS AN ANIME ABOUT FARMING? I LOVE IT. Despite the fact that this anime is an, well anime, it feels beyond real and raw. I've never seen a farm or any agricultural facility in my life and this was eye opening. I knew about slaughter houses and generallybasics of farming but seeing how hard it is and how much effort and thought goes into it in the eyes of an anime is amazing. 


My thought through out can be summed in one sentence. "I wanna be a vegetarian but meat is just too good." 


--Characters--


One of my favorite things about this anime is how easy it is to relate with the main character, he is human, has feelings, doesn't have any experience with the field and he's just a teenager trying to figure out what to do with his life. He is trying to be happy and find a dream. That is so easy to relate and it makes it so easy to immediately like the guy. 


Other charecters are also well thought and has their unique personalities and you end up remembering them at the end of the show.


--Art--


Art is in my opinion pretty generic and a style that you can see in a lot of anime series. The animals are cute, people has their unique styles and the surroundings are also good, they are not great but they are definitely not just okay either. It's enjoyable and you don't end up thinking well it could've been better which is just enough. 


--Sound--


Except the opening and endings which are just fine, not memorable, the general score is also not memorable but sound is not the thing they clearly focused on and I didn't really care about it either so It's fine.


--Final Thoughts-- 


My overall score is going to be 8 because it's a show that I'd definitely recommend and I enjoyed it a lot. It's a nice escape from that action fantasy genre that's everywhere and classic high school slice of life romcom dramas. So if you're looking for a good enjoyable and quirky show this is your show!

I really liked this anime. This anime made you feel a certain way. It made you get attached to the animals. I mean, THEY'RE ANIMALS FOR GOODNESS' SAKE. I'm quite surprised that I liked this anime. I'm not into agriculture, but I enjoyed this anime. The reason I watched this anime was because of an anime podcast I listened to (Anime Addicts Anonymous). This anime was included in one of their Anime Oscars, I do believe. Onto da other stuff! 
I really liked the way this anime looked. This was the first time that I ever saw an anime that had a look like this.Sure, the humans looked a little weird at first look, but, it grew on me. I grew to really like the way it looks. The humans may look a little weird, but the animals are ADORABLE. The calves are so cute looking. Pork Bowl as a little piglet is probably the cutest. *sniff* *sniff*


The story was pretty good. Well, in my opinion at least. I can't really explain why I like it, but I just do. Can't you relate? The characters were okay, a little better than mediocre. I don't think they were your "run-of-the-mill" characters, but they were pretty darn close to it. Mikage is just your average oblivious anime girl. Hachiken is your MC who likes the girl who is oblivious to his feelings. In this first season, Pork Bowl was my favorite character, if he even counts as one.


I absolutely LOVED the music for this anime. It really sets one into the mood that the creators probably meant the watchers to feel. The opening sounded strange at first, but it really grew on me. I liked the ending right from the start. I feel it really fits the anime as a whole.  


The anime was extremely enjoyable. The animals really made it very enjoyable to watch. I liked to see them every episode. I grew to look forward to it. The art made it enjoyable as well. I feel like I'm just repeating what I've already stated. Oh well. That's life.


Overall, I would rate this anime a nine out of ten. I would definitely recommend this anime to pretty much everyone and anyone. It's just that amazing of an anime. :D

January Challenge
Task 1: Watch an anime from Gourmet Challenge
Possible spoilers, proceed with caution. 
Slice of life has always been a tough genre for me to really get into. I’ve probably started five or six shows and dropped them all episode three, just because I’ve found them boring. Nozaki-kun I think was the first slice of life show I had finished and enjoyed. This is the one I wish I had started with. 
I’ve grown to appreciate the “characters doing stuff” genre thanks to this. It starts off as just seeing the life of this kid going to a high school he isn’t quite sure about.He meets new people and ends up enjoying his school. It’s a simple enough plot, but it’s feels like more than that. The characters feel more fleshed out and it had a lot of heart. 


As I said before, the story is simple, and something we’ve seen before multiple times. It’s the story of Yuugo Hachiken, a kid from the city trying to escape from his parents by going to a boarding school in the middle of nowhere. He notices that everyone around him already has a Dream for what they want in life after high school, whether it be taking over the family farming business, becoming a veterinarian, or becoming a national baseball star to support their family. Yuugo on the other hand, just wants to stay away from his family and be the top student of his class. 


There are so many things that show Yuugo’s development throughout the series. He starts off as a kid who just wants to do good in all his classes, and eventually graduate. Later on, he realizes he has to take a club in order to graduate, and he chooses the equestrian club as a girl he likes is in the club. Eventually he develops a deeper love for animals, and it shows when he is helping with the pigs, and sees Pork Bowl, a weak little piglet that is in danger of getting killed for not having enough meat. Hachiken is now determined to help this little guy out, even though everyone warns him about getting too close to farm animals. 


Another way you see Hachiken’s development is through his sleep schedule. He started out by not being able to get up at 5:30 with everyone else for practicums, and woke up earlier to help with horses, and even earlier after that on his own at 3:00 to help Pork Bowl and the horses, all before breakfast. The fact that he is willing to give up this time for his school, his friends, and his animals shows how much he has grown throughout the eleven episode season. 


I think a more interesting part of the series is when Yuugo goes to stay with Mikage for the summer and works part time of her farm. He learns to deal with deaths of animals, and then the consumption of them by skinning and gutting a deer that was ran over (this sounds dark and gloomy but I promise it’s more light hearted). Also, seeing Yuugo and Mikage’s relationship grow over time was nice to see as well. 


I think my only main problem with the series is the use of montages towards the end. I think there were three montages towards the end of the series that felt like they were there to make you get emotional, and while the first on seemed to work, it felt manipulative once the second one came and the sad music started playing again. I just feel like it could’ve worked better with a different way of getting the audience to feel emotional. 


All in all, this is a show I see myself coming back to at some point, and I will be seeing season 2 sometime in the near future. So far the shows aired on noitaminA (the block that aired this) have done well for me. I enjoyed this and Wotakoi very much, and will definitely get to the show they’re airing this winter, and might do a marathon of their shows as well.

A review of perhaps the most Japanese show this season. This is an anime about hard work, hard work and the fruits of your labor, as well as other bits and pieces along the way. Not only is it Japanese, it’s also original!
WRITING (9/10)
*Characters
The characters in Gin no Saji feel very real, even if a bit exaggerated as in most anime. All the characters except the main one come from rural areas, and are already familiar with the setting. They’re strong, knowledgeable and know their stuff when it comes to agriculture. Tamako, for example, is a ruthless business woman but at the same time showshints of playfulness and friendliness. The main star, Hachiken, is in a position most of us have been in: wandering aimlessly without any goals or aspirations while the people around him all seem to have their futures figured out. This is what makes Hachiken relatable, he arrives at the location of the show, an agricultural school, simply to get away from his old and pointless life. What happens later is a transformation from cynical city boy to a responsible student as he rapidly learns from everything and everyone around him. He was given a fresh start in a totally different environment and as a result of that grew as a person. The large supporting cast all seem to have something to teach him, which only proves the importance of seeing a situation from different perspectives, from the eyes of others. Everyone are fun to watch and are characters you don’t get bored with, all with their own quirks and talents.


*Overall writing


As I said in the introduction, Gin no Saji is both original and -very- Japanese. Hachiken learns about the importance of hard work, responsibility and teamwork, which is easy to get inspired by. A teacher likens Hachiken’s entry into the class to an animal from a different tribe joining a new one. He shares his own thoughts and perspectives which help the class grow and evolve as a whole, and in return receives their knowledge. Aside from being inspiring and entertaining, Gin no Saji is also educational. The viewers learn about the agricultural life, how it is to work at a farm and even brings up how little they are paid. They show how cattle are brought up, how cows are milked, how pigs make it from the pen to the slaughterhouse, etc etc. One of the longer story arcs involves Hachiken and Pork Bowl, the runt of a litter of piglets. Hachiken decides to rear Pork Bowl from the smallest pig in the litter to the same size as its siblings. Here, the show takes the opportunity to deal the themes of attachment and loss. Needless to say, it’s both sad and beautiful in its own way.


These themes have of course been explored before, but not in such a fresh way as Gin no Saji does it. I look forward to every episode just to see what’s going to happen! This show gets interesting right away, and you feel compelled to watch. Even if the events are trivial, they could be totally foreign to many of us who live in the cities. It’s just such a great display of hard work, dedication, friendship and growth delivered in such a simple way that is easy to absorb and enjoy.


*Ending


“Don’t look down on yourself for running. Make it meaningful by making something out of it.”


In the end, we see the value of the lessons Hachiken has learned, about the country life and about himself. We see how far he’s come, how he now has plenty of friends and truly enjoys life at Ezonoo. The ending is left open so they’ll have little issue with introducing the second season, but at the same time there is a feeling is completion. It feels like Hachiken has found his place, and even if his future is still uncertain, right now he’s where he wants to be.


AUDIO (8/10)


* Voice Acting/Sound


The characters are brought to life with fitting voices for the roles. The large and tough third year students all sounds manly and gruff, ,even with their relatively young voices. Tamako’s voice adheres to her role with a hilariously mature voice and speech pattern that you really think of her as a step above all the others while Hachiken has the voice of a regular guy, with a sometimes uninterested tone which fits him well. The sounds themselves blend in well with the show. It’s not easy to comment on background noises since a well-designed background should go unnoticed and blend in with the rest of the show, which is exactly what it does.


*Music


I give the music a high score mostly because of the outro: a catchy Japanese country tune that was well chosen. I really love when an anime decides to pick a different kind of genre for their openings and endings instead of a throwaway pop song. Good going!


ART (9/10)

The campus is huge and well-drawn, with plenty of key locations and life-like details. Just looking at the equipment used in the school’s facilities is educational and fascinating due to its realism. What surprised me is the light use of 3D to show the animals (mostly cows) and that they actually show plenty of blood, all in context of course. At one point, Hachiken is called upon to skin a roadkill, and a documentary details the slaughterhouse process, including draining a pig of blood.


Character designs are fairly normal, with some being designed in a way that complements their personality. Visual gags here are kept to a minimum and realism is the aim.


YURI RATING (0/10)


Not even goggles will get you any readings here. Abandon all hope.


OVERALL (9/10)


Gin no Saji excellently captures Japanese values about hard work, dedication and the importance of your “group”, while at the same time cherishing the individual and his or her own goals and dreams. It offers a close look at the rural, agricultural life of Japan, both its ups and downs, which makes it a compelling watch because of the unusual setting it has. A competent show all around, it sets out on a journey which teacher, entertains and questions, all in one finely crafted package. It’s a true joy to watch Gin no Saji, and I hope the second season will take the original concept,  improve and expand upon it, as a sequel should.

They say it's not possible to succeed in life without having a dream or any ambition. But are dreams really that important if you want to achieve big things and live out a prosperous life? This is the question that revolves around the head of our protagonist in Gin No Saji, a brilliant anime that will probably be over-looked by most.
STORY:
To keep things simple, Gin No Saji isn't your average SOL anime. The show is unique in most aspects, starting from the fact that it actually takes place in an agricultural school to the vast diversity of characters with their own relate-able and realistic backgroundsand problems. Another big factor is the sheer amount of educational knowledge that can be obtained by watching this show, which explains how hard yet fruitful the life of farming can be. The show, on the whole, paces along very well, although it could have used a bit more time in a few episodes.


ART:

The art was very fluid throughout the series. The scenery is beautiful and fascinating; the vibrant display of the colours used give the anime a really pacifying and reassuring atmosphere which might also put you at ease. The animation is consistent throughout, which was reassuring.


SOUND:

The only downside of the series. The soundtrack was largely disappointing. Both the opening and the ending were mediocre at best and I really don't think I'll go back and listen to them again. The BGM was okay in most cases but they were, on occasions, completely missing from the scenes in question. The voice-acting, though, was pretty good and the VAs deserve, at least, some credit.


CHARACTER:

In one word, INCREDIBLE. Starting from the protagonist to the characters who spend a small amount of time on-screen, nobody's representation is over-done. Each of the main characters and supporting protagonists have aims and histories you can (probably) relate to, and nothing really feels out of place. The dialogues are also very solid. The jokes were mostly hilarious too, although they did on occasion feel out-of-place or over-used.


ENJOYMENT:

In general, Gin No Saji has been a very enjoyable anime. Sans the music aspect, the show was outstanding.


OVERALL:

Gin No Saji is truly one of those rare animes that will just captivate you and keep you glued to the screen, making you want more and more as each episode finishes. The shows that it's perfectly alright to start all over again and that you should never be scared of taking an unconventional step.


SCORES IN BRIEF:

Story- 9/10

Art- 8/10

Sound - 6/10

Characters - 9/10

Enjoyment - 8/10

OVERALL - 8/10

A not so hidden gem that is one of the best things you could suggest to somebody if they're looking for a good "slice of life" anime. 
Gin no Saji has managed to deliver a great sense of realism without losing that wholesome anime feel (wholesome being a relative term). It offers a nice amount of teenage angst, but not so much as to turn it into a melodrama. 
It livens the whole rural agricultural Japan setting and the plethora of educational nuances it has are both accurate and interesting. Even with my laughably little knowledge of farming, it actually tugs me to learn orat least spark some interest in the craft. And normally when an anime does that, it's a good one. 


My only particular complaints would be that sometimes the pacing does get a little weak and character development isn't that widespread. 


Though I'm not saying that the characters aren't well developed, quite the opposite to be exact; Everyone in the anime almost feels alive. The main and even some side characters' developments were amazingly on point. Which kind of saddens me that not everybody gets a similar amount of development. 


But those are easily overlooked with how good the anime is. Partner this up with the great pieces from Miwa and Sukima Switch and you got yourself some fresh, charcoal grilled to perfection, Gin no Saji. Something your really should indulge in.

Silver Spoon was such a good watch for me. I'm not one to watch Slice of Life Animes; most have never appealed to me. There's was something different about this one though, maybe it was the agricultural twist? Or the fact that the manga was drawn by Hiromu Arakawa. I  don't know, but I'm so glad that I gave it a shot.
     I really connected with the main character, Hachiken, everything he goes throughout the show just resonated in me somehow; its something I have never felt in another anime. I could only think "Isthis me in another world? Another life?" and the supporting cast is just a fricken' great, there really isn't any character I am just utterly displeased with. All of them are pretty well rounded and fit into their trope accordingly. \n
     The music isn't spectacular, but that is honestly fine. Its there to give you the proper emotions and that's all this show needs honestly. The opening theme and closing theme are both pretty good, I especially love the ending, something about it makes me happy. \n
     The art is really nice to look at, and most of the animals that are depicted are animated very well, aside from a few horse shots. Still, it was great to look at the scenery whenever they showed off their environmental skills and the characters all look great and pretty distinct from one another. So there's no mix up of "Is that the same spikey haired guy?" \n
   All in all, Silver Spoon was a good, funny, and actually thought provoking anime. Will I continue to watch into Season Two? You betcha! Thanks for reading if you made it all the way down here, and I hope you enjoy the amazing eleven episode runtime. \n
~Cheers~ Tom

*Spoiler free-ish review*
Silver spoon is the very definition of "Don't judge the book by It's cover"
Silver spoon is a anime/manga from the Author of the famous Fullmetal Alchemist and tells a story about Hachiken, a smart guy who doesn't know what he wants from his life. 
He is cornered by his parents who want him to join boarding school for his destined university. 
Finally he has mental breakdown and says screw it and joins a agricultural school far away from his home.
Lesson by lesson he begins to understand the lives of the people who live on the countryside and how they life from hand tomouth. \n\n
Hachi is conflicted since many of his fellow classmates come from big old households who feel the agricultural school as necessity for inheriting the family business while Hachi joined the school to escape his past life.\n\n
Silver Spoon makes the watcher question his morals and ethical choices. They show how hard living by agriculture really is in realistically manner. \n
It's easy to get in debt, hurt yourself from overwork and most important is to commit your whole life for your craft. \n
It also makes you question your own morals and think about animal rights. It's very refreshing to see how boldly they show the process of raising the livestock with care only to have them end up as their livelihood.\n\n
All the ethical and moral questions aside, Silver spoon has this lovely SOL and romance as part of it. I enjoyed and cherished every single episode.\n
The OP and ED set the feel and they're perfect for this show. Especially the ED is heartwarming.\n\n
I totally recommend you watch the anime and read manga afterwards. This series is a masterpiece within It's own genre.\n

I never thought I would enjoy a SoL anime (about farming no less) as much as I did Gin no Saji. And from the great Arakawa Hiromu (of FMA fame) herself. I admit, I was hooked in by the authors name and jumped in blind but it became one of the best decisions I made in my anime watching life;) Here's why.
Story/Characters: 
The main protagonist this time is this young, bespectacled lad named Hachiken Yugo who is very much a city boy hailing from Sapporo. After failing his entrance exams for his chosen school he decides to enroll at Yezo Agricultural High thinking that hewould have an easier time preparing for college if the academic level was a bit lower than usual. Little did he know this decision would lead him to a great journey of self discovery (Cheesy? I know... Just work w/ me here...). 


It might sound no different from all adolescent coming of age dramas we've encountered but trust me it's not. It's one of the very few series where you feel the authors sincerity in the story. Arakawa sensei really put a lot of thought and heart into making this series and it shows. 


Add a memorable cast of characters, good pacing, and the trademark Arakawa humor and you have yourself a real good show.The issues it tackles are things we often take for granted (Pork Bowl for example) but the way the show presents them and the conclusions it offers really hit you deep in the gut. There isn't so much heavy drama but it still manages to touch the audience. That in itself is testament to how good the storytelling in this series is.  


Speaking of conclusions, the show doesn't actually present a definite one but just basically says, and I quote, "never stop trying to understand". There is no definite answer. But whatever decision you come to just be sure to face it head on. This really got to me personally.


Art/Sound:


A-1 really shows their stuff when working w/ SoL shows and Gin no Saji is no exception. The backdrops are filled w/ detail and the animation is smooth. The OP/ED are catchy and the OST is appropriate.


Overall: 


A very enjoyable watch. One of the few animes that prompted me to read the manga straight away. This is one of those gems where the different elements merge to paint a beautiful montage w/out anything feeling out of place at all. The warmth and problems that accompany human relations, the farming backdrop, coming of age, comedy... All merge into one great SoL series. A definite must watch for those who like the genre.

When you hear the title "Silver Spoon," it sounds like something very shiny or quirky--in a magical way. Well, that is how I thought when someone told me to watch this show. But, it wasn't what I expected to be.
Silver Spoon has a Slice of Life genre. I like the genre but I felt a little reluctant at first because it is not what I expected, but I still continued... and were really surprised because it's just really fun to watch. I thought it would be fun at first then falls eventually, but no.
And it's not just being fun to watch or anything like that.It has a message which I related myself so much onto. It talks about dreams, family, and friendship.


I liked the show, not because it was relatable for some reasons, but because it helps you understand what life really is--especially for people like teens or people who are trying to find themselves--for those who are searching who they really are, etc.


It has a lot to tell about thriving on something despite anything that could be holding you back. But, it's not always perfect. And not all things can go perfectly. So, imperfections are also part of living.


Well, it would be spoiling if I'd write more. The thing is, I was really surprised by this show. It's far from what I'm thinking it should be. It is a must-watch, indeed. It is a little underrated. So, it needs more attention, and will surely be loved if seen.


Well, I can guarantee!

Silver Spoon is one of the best animes I've watched all around, with great writing, characters, and moments (which makes sense, considering it was based off of the manga by Hiromu Arakawa, that's right, the brilliant woman behind Fullmetal Alchemist)

It's a slice of life anime with a lot of great moments, funny, sad, heartfelt. It was written extremely well (and, as a note, after the second season there is more content in the manga, so if you can't get enough of the story, don't worry, she's still writing more of it)
